comments.author: @AK-nm7gv
comments.text:
Covishield causes side effect of thrombotic thrombocytopenia due to which there is clotting of blood in the coranary arteries or arteries supplying the brain. This leads to people suffering from myocardial infarction (heart attack) and brain stroke. Significant number of young and middle aged adults in the last 2-3 years have died of heart attack as a side effect of Covishield. The long term future risk of getting a heart attack for all those who have received Covishield vaccine, though low, is not zero.
The greedy pharma companies didn't put a label about this side effect in their Phase IV Clinical trials, and had to reveal it out in the court once litigation charges were pressed. Soon, this vaccine will be withdrawn from the market, and no one will talk about it.
Any drug that is introduced into the market requires good amount of research and clinical trials, which takes minimum of 10 years. Imagine getting a vaccine in 1 year; you would hardly know the efficacy and long term adverse effects. This is what happened with Covishield vaccine.

All those who are preparing for NEET UG, all the best. Work hard and don't spend your time watching YouTube videos that's not related to your preparation. You will always long to be a doctor and never become one. All those who will be doctors, will never spend their time here.
Being from aiims, people can have their own agenda. Don't get into it but use your own brain.

replies.author: @NurseMJ986
replies.text: I was a Covid Nurse. I know it’s hard to believe if you have not seen how sick people were. Some of them still have long Covid symptoms to this day. I initially did not want the shot, but the whole hospital was full of covid patients. We were normally a post op unit and we had all covid patients who were every sick and should have been in ICU but ICU was full. We have 6 (30) unit beds in the hospital with different specialties normally but were all covid units during the surge. Not counting the critical care units and even PACU which was an overflow ICU at that time since surgeries were cancelled. It was like entering a war zone literally. The question I asked myself, should I go to war without ammunition? Knowing fully well a lot of patients have died including nurses? ( these were previously healthy patients, no co-morbidities), or do I take a chance not knowing if my body can take the exposure to the virus being in close close contact with these sick patients????

replies.author: @blackfeathercrafts
replies.text:
@@NurseMJ986 luckily I was working pediatric home care with heart transplant kids and my little patients didn’t get it. My wife however was in an MS research study. 2 PCA came to work and didn’t know they had Covid. This was in 2020 before the vaccine.

Half of the patients died and the University of Minnesota had to close the study.

Had I not just came home from work when I did, she would have collapsed and no one would have been there. This was 2 months after the infection. I’m glad I could get CPR going. Her recovery has been slow, and we both have long haulers.

I’m glad nurses like you were in the hospitals trying to save people. I wasn’t able to join you in that direct line of fire. I’m also glad you came out of the war zone. I hope you are well.

I’ve been an RN since 1996. I had never imagined anything like this.

replies.author: @sweetpie7919
replies.text:
My dead uncle coughed for more than a week. He said covid wasn't a big deal for a strong guy like him. If you only got sick for a week I am genuinely happy for you. But it hits everyone differently. For my dad it was like a bad flu for 3 days, then he was suddenly fine, it was kinda weird how he just snapped out of it. For my mom it was a month of hell because her fever wouldn't break, she kept passing out. She said it's the worst thing she's ever gone through and it made her very careful not to get sick again. Both my parents are really healthy, no health problems, don't smoke, only drink on holidays, very active.

I normally catch everything. I haven't gotten covid, no one in my house has. But we've all been vaccinated and we did the whole mask thing. It was kinda great how no got sick with anything for a good 3 years. What a nice break. But alas one of my kids got a cold and passed it to us all, oh well. It wasn't so bad. I feel like the break from being sick strengthened me. My body really needed the break.

replies.author: @ChristinaPhillips-kc5my
replies.text:
@@BillGraper Tylenol? It's still on shelves everywhere. You just have to not exceed the max dose on the bottle and not pop the max dose every day. It's meant for occasional pain. Not surprising that not using something as intended ends badly. Nothing is guaranteed and nothing is perfect, natural or less natural. Life is a game of risk management. Bodies are not identical enough to accurately predict what a specific individual's reaction to something will be. So you look at a bunch of people who did one thing and the same number of people that did the other and control for as many variables as possible and see which group has worse results. As it turns out, like with any other vaccine where there's less to react to that in a pathogen infection, getting the virus does more damage.

If you react to the virus like a bad cold, you won't react worse to the vaccine. Because both sets if symptoms are from your immune response to the same thing.

comments.author: @mickenziefriesen5871
comments.text: I work in healthcare in Canada and I do not recommend the shot. If you are healthy, have no preexisting conditions, don’t bother. I’ve met too many patients with amputations due to blood clots after receiving the shot.

replies.author: @theozzy4717
replies.text: What's the benefit of taking it?

replies.author: @mickenziefriesen5871
replies.text:
@@theozzy4717 (sorry this is long)
Short version: it’s each individuals choice, but I would say only benefit would be for individuals with pre-existing conditions, as it will lessen symptom severity if they catch it, which for those people, could be significant to keeping them healthy.

Long version: just like with other vaccines it is not a cure, nor does it stop the spread of a virus. It simply is used to lessen the symptoms of a virus if you do catch it. It doesn’t make someone more safe to be around, only helps that individuals chances of having a Severe reaction to the virus. Not lessens their chances of catching it. I would say if you are elderly, or have pre-existing conditions or autoimmune issues, then perhaps it has more benefits vs the risks. (If you have underlying lung issues your lungs might not be able to recover as well) However I don’t think it has much benefit when you look at the risks for individuals who are young (I’d say 50s and under) and healthy. If you’re older but have great health then again, it’s risk vs reward. Especially kids I don’t think they need to be getting them if they are healthy active kids. Natural immunity is always better than a man made solution, however some people can’t risk that due to (as said before) already existing health conditions.
It should always be up to an individuals personal choice, however they should also always know the risks and benefits. Unfortunately many of the risks and usually health guidelines that are supposed to be followed were scrapped in order to release a vaccine quickly. (Ex: miscarriage rates were public knowledge until, particularly in 3rd trimester, the rates started increasing, and suddenly they removed public access.) Which honestly makes me doubt motives behind such a vaccine.

comments.text:
Soke problems I have with this:

1) they don't explain what exceptionally rare means

2) the study didn't establish a causal link and doesn't rule out confounding factors (e.g. there might be other health conditions, diet or environmental factors)

3) none of these types of reports ever provide context to the risk. For example, out of all the reported potential side effects any vaccine, only 1/2-2/3 are actually related. With COVID that's expected to be lower because of people being convinced that the vaccine will cause harm. But even if we assume all the reports are due to the vaccine, that still places the risk at approximately 1/60th the chance you'll be struck by a vehicle this year. And any risks from the vaccine are far less than the risks associated with catching COVID while unvaccinated.

If you or anyone you know has sudden onset of SEVERE dermatitis that started after their vaccination, please look into Pityriasis Lichenoides, or PLEVA. It is NOT just atopic dermatitis or prurigo nodularis.
